Du bist ein Evaluator für medizinische Austrittsberichte einer Psychiatrie. Prüfe den Austrittsbericht auf fehlende medizinische Informationen and gib für jeden Abschnitt eine Ausgabe nach folgendem Schema:

* `"Abschnittsname": 1` wenn der Abschnitt medizinisch vollständig ist
* `"Abschnittsname": 0` wenn Informationen fehlen (z.B. Diagnosen, Befunde, Medikation) mit kurzer Begründung in einem Satz.

models.mistral:7b-instruct:
1. "Eingang": 1
2. "Diagnosen": 0, Diagnosen sind nicht genau angegeben. Es sind nur ICD-10-Codes erwähnt (F33.2, F90.0, St.n. F10.0), aber keine weiteren Angaben zu den jeweiligen Störungen gemacht.
3. "Psychotherapeutische Themen": 1, der Patient wird in der Therapie lernen, negative Gedanken zu identifizieren und hinterzufragen.
4. "Medikation bei Austritt": 1, das Medikament ist aufgeführt, aber die Dosis und Angaben zur Verabreichung fehlen. Es gibt auch keine Information über die Medikamente, die vorher eingenommen wurden.
5. "Verlauf": 0, es gibt keine Informationen zum weiteren Verlauf des Patienten.
6. "Hausärztliche Weiterbetreuung": 1, die Hausärztliche Weiterbetreuung wird durch Dr. med. Grundversorgung erfolgen.
7. "Empfehlungen": 0, es gibt keine Empfehlungen für zukünftige Maßnahmen oder weiteres Vorgehen.
8. "Beendigung": 1, es ist angekündigt, dass das Dokument ohne Unterschrift gültig ist.

models.mistral:7b-instruct:
Dear Ms. Kollegin and Mr. Kollege,

We report on the patient Eggli, whom we have diagnosed with a severe recurrent depressive episode. In our integrated treatment program, he participated in multimodal therapy including medical-pharmacological treatment, psychotherapy (individual and group), and counseling services.

In pharmacological terms, we decided to start Venlafaxine at an initial dose of 37.5 mg per day, which was gradually increased to the target dose of 75 mg per day. During the dosage process, he experienced typical but tolerable side effects such as nausea, headache, dizziness, and sweating that subsided completely over time. Labor and EKG control tests were always normal.

In terms of psychotherapeutic themes, it was found that Mr. Eggli frequently had negative thoughts about his professional performance, which led to feelings of worthlessness. In therapy, he learned to identify these thoughts and question them. A coping strategy developed consisted of collecting proofs of his abilities by recording past successes or reflecting on positive feedback from colleagues and superiors. Cognitive restructuring techniques were also used to change his thinking patterns and boost his self-esteem. Relaxation exercises and stress management techniques were also taught to help him cope better with professional challenges and improve his wellbeing.

Upon completion of treatment, he returned to his rental apartment and existing employment. His condition improved over time in terms of thought patterns, motivation, mood, and future perspective. At discharge, a nearly remitted depressive syndrome without signs of acute suicidality was observed. We discharged Mr. Eggli in stable mental health and with no indications of acute self-harm or harm to others.

Medication at discharge:
- Lisinopril 5 mg Film-coated tablet (Lisinopril)
- Venlafaxine 75 mg Film-coated tablet (Venlafaxine)
- Dafalgan 500 mg Tablet (Paracetamol)

Procedure: 1-0-0-0 (Tablet)
Initial dose: 14.05.2020
Maintenance dose: 14.05.2020
Reserve dose: 1 tablet per day; maximum daily dose: 3 tablets
Maximum/24 hours: max. 3 tablets

For ambulatory psychiatric follow-up, we arranged an appointment for Mr. Eggli with Dr. Zwanghaft on June 31, 2024.
Primary care will continue to be provided by Dr. med. Grundversorgung.
We recommend a lifelong abstinence from alcohol. After stabilization in the ambulatory setting, we suggest tapering off Venlafaxine no earlier than 12-24 months, or considering additional dosing if there is a relapse. We also recommend continuing outpatient psychotherapy, which Mr. Eggli can discuss with Dr. Zwanghaft.

Please feel free to contact us if you have any questions.

Best regards,
[Your Name]

models.mistral:7b-instruct:
Dear Dr. Anja Zwanghaft,

   We are reporting on the patient Eggli, whom we had in our stationary and later in our (partial) stationary treatment from March 1st to March 29th, 20XX, and again from April 14th to May 14th, 20XX, at our clinic.

   After extensive examinations, we diagnosed him with a severe recurrent depressive episode. We considered an uncertain avoidant personality structure but did not diagnose a personality disorder due to the strongly expressed affective symptoms at this time. No specific, organic etiology was evident, especially in light of an unremarkable MRI.

   During his stay at our clinic, Mr. Eggli participated in our multimodal treatment program that included medical pharmacological treatment, psychotherapy, and social support.

   Pharmacologically, we decided to start Venlafaxine with a low initial dose of 37.5 mg per day, gradually increasing to the target dose of 75 mg per day. During the dosage adjustment process, typical but tolerable side effects occurred, including nausea, headaches, dizziness, and excessive sweating. These resolved completely over time. Routine EKGs and laboratory tests were unremarkable.

   In psychotherapeutic sessions, we identified that Mr. Eggli often had negative thoughts about his professional performance, which led to feelings of worthlessness. He learned to identify these thoughts and question them during therapy. A coping strategy developed involved gathering evidence of his abilities by recording past successes or reflecting on positive feedback from colleagues or superiors. Cognitive restructuring techniques were also applied to change his thinking patterns and boost his self-worth. Relaxation exercises and stress management techniques were also taught to help him cope better with professional challenges and improve his wellbeing.

   After the treatment, Mr. Eggli returned to his rental apartment and continued his employment. His condition improved significantly during this time.

   At discharge, the following medications were prescribed: Lisinopril 5 mg film-coated tablets (Lisinopril), Venlafaxine 75 mg film-coated tablets (Venlafaxine), and Dafalgan 500 mg tablets (Paracetamol). The instructions are as follows:

   Lisinopril 5 mg film-coated tablets (Lisinopril) - Take 1 tablet daily, in reserve; 1 tablet per day maximum/24 hours: max. 3 tablets

   Venlafaxine 75 mg film-coated tablets (Venlafaxine) - Take 1 tablet daily

   Dafalgan 500 mg tablets (Paracetamol) - As needed for pain relief

   For further ambulatory psychiatric care, we scheduled an appointment with Dr. Zwanghaft on June 31st, 20XX. His primary care physician, Dr. med. Grundversorgung, will continue to provide ongoing medical care.

   We recommend lifelong alcohol abstinence. After stabilization in the ambulatory setting, we suggest a gradual tapering of Venlafaxine starting at least 12-24 months later, provided there is no deterioration in condition. In such cases, another dose adjustment may be necessary. We also recommend continued ambulatory psychotherapy. Mr. Eggli wishes to discuss this with Dr. Zwanghaft.

   If you have any questions, please feel free to contact us. This document has been electronically reviewed and is also valid without a signature.

   Best regards,

   [Your Name]
   [Your Position]

models.mistral:7b-instruct:
Dear Colleague,

We are reporting on the above-mentioned patient, Marius Eggli, who was under our stationary and subsequently partial hospital care from March 1st to April 14th, 2020. Upon discharge, he is in a stable psychological state and there are no indications of acute self or external danger.

Diagnosis: Based on depressive mood, reduced drive, feelings of emptiness, self-deprecation, guilt feelings, sleep disturbances, and pessimistic future perspective, as well as indicators of previous depressive episodes, we diagnosed a severe recurring depressive episode. We also considered an uncertain avoidant personality structure but did not diagnose a personality disorder due to the current strongly pronounced affective symptomatology. There were no indications for a specific organic etiology, particularly in the light of an unremarkable MRI.

Treatment and Course: During the stationary stay, Mr. Eggli participated in our multimodal treatment program that included pharmacological therapy, psychotherapeutic individual and group therapy, as well as support services. Medication-wise, we decided on Venlafaxine with an initial dose of 37.5 mg per day to be increased up to a maximum dose of 75 mg per day. During the dosage process, typical but tolerable side effects occurred, including nausea, headache, dizziness, and increased sweating, which resolved completely in the course. Routine ECGs and laboratory tests were always unremarkable.

In psychotherapeutic terms, it was found that Mr. Eggli often has negative thoughts about his professional performance, leading to feelings of worthlessness. In therapy, he learned to identify these thoughts and question them. A coping strategy was developed by collecting evidence of his abilities by recalling past successes or positive feedback from colleagues or superiors. Cognitive restructuring techniques were used in individual and group sessions to change his thought patterns and strengthen his self-esteem. Relaxation exercises and stress management techniques were also taught to help him better cope with professional challenges and improve his well-being.

Upon discharge, Mr. Eggli returned to his rented apartment and existing employment. In the course of improvement, thoughts, mood, drive, and future perspective improved. At discharge, a largely remitted depressive syndrome without indications of acute suicidality was present. We are discharging Mr. Eggli in a stable psychological state and with no indications of acute self or external danger into his previously known living and working conditions.

Medication at Discharge: Venlafaxine 75 mg per day (Venlafaxine), Lisinopril 5 mg per day (Lisinopril), Dalfalgan 500 mg per tablet as needed (Paracetamol)

Follow-up: For Mr. Eggli, we organized a follow-up appointment with Dr. Zwanghaft on June 30th, 2020. His primary care will continue to be provided by Dr. med. Grundversorgung. We recommend permanent abstinence from alcohol.

After stabilization in the outpatient setting, we recommend a tapering off of Venlafaxine at least after approximately 12-24 months, if necessary, another dosage increase would be considered. We recommend continued ambulatory psychotherapeutic treatment, which Mr. Eggli wishes to discuss with Dr. Zwanghaft.

Please feel free to contact us if you have any questions. This document was electronically reviewed and is valid without a signature.

Best regards,

[Your Name]

models.mistral:7b-instruct:
Diagnosis:
   - Schwerer rezidivierender depressiver Episode
   - Differentialdiagnostisch wurde auch eine unsicher-vermeidende Persönlichkeitsstruktur erwogen, wobei wir eine Persönlichkeitsstörung aufgrund der aktuell stark ausgeprägten affektiven Symptomatik nicht stellten.
   - Keine Hinweise für eine spezifische, organische Genese ergaben sich nicht, insbesondere bei unauffälligem MRI.

   Pharmacological Treatment:
   - Venlafaxine with a low initial dose of 37.5 mg per day to be gradually increased up to the target dose of 75 mg per day.
   - During the dosage adjustment process, typical but tolerable side effects occurred, such as mild nausea, headache, dizziness, and excessive sweating. These symptoms resolved completely over time.
   - Follow-up EKG and lab tests were always normal.

   Psychotherapeutic Themes:
   - Herr Eggli often had negative thoughts about his professional performance, which led to feelings of worthlessness. In therapy, he learned to identify these thoughts and question them.
   - A coping strategy developed was to collect evidence of his abilities by recording past successes or reflecting on positive feedback from colleagues or superiors.
   - Cognitive restructuring techniques were used to change his thought patterns and strengthen his self-worth. Relaxation and stress management techniques were also provided to help him cope better with work challenges and improve his well-being.

   Social Situation:
   - After completing treatment, the patient returned to his rental apartment and maintained existing employment.

   Somatic Co-findings:
   - No significant co-findings (i.e., no additional diagnoses requiring ongoing treatment).

   Course:
   - The patient's thinking improved, as did motivation, mood, and future perspective. At discharge, there was a largely remitted depressive syndrome without signs of acute suicidal ideation. We released Herr Eggli in a stable mental state with no indications of acute self- or/and other-harm potential in his known living and working conditions.

   Medications at Discharge:
   - Lisinopril 5 mg film tablet (Lisinopril)
   - Venlafaxine 75 mg film tablet (Venlafaxine)
   - Paracetamol 500 mg tablet (Paracetamol)
   - Procedure: 1-0-0-0 (tablet)
   - Start date: May 14, 2020
   - Frequency: Daily
   - In reserve: 1 (max. 3) tablets per day; Maximum/24 hours: max. 3 tablets

   Outpatient Psychiatric Follow-up:
   - An outpatient appointment was organized for Herr Eggli with Dr. Zwanghaft on June 30, 2024.
   - General practitioner follow-up continues kindly under Dr. med. Grundversorgung.
   - We recommend permanent alcohol abstinence.
   - After stabilization in the outpatient setting, we recommend a tapering off of Venlafaxine as early as approximately 12 to 24 months, with reconsideration of another dosage increase if there is a worsening of condition.
   - We recommend continued ambulatory psychotherapy for Herr Eggli; he should discuss this with Dr. Zwanghaft.
   - In case of further questions, we are very happy to assist.

   General Recommendations for Discharge Reports:
   - Write the report in a manner that the patient can read and understand. If desired, the letter may be provided to the patient. This document was electronically viewed and is valid even without a signature.
   - For capacity-competent patients, we typically suggest providing the letter, if requested.
   - In this case, the patient's discharge report has been written in German, as per his preference.

In diesem Fall handelt es sich um einen fiktiven, sehr detaillierten Bericht über die Behandlung eines Patienten namens Herr Eggli, der an einer schweren rezidivierenden depressiven Episode leidet. Der Bericht enthält medizinische Befunde, Diagnosen, Therapieansätze und Empfehlungen für die weitere Betreuung des Patienten.

Im Allgemeinen werden solche detaillierten Fallberichte in der Gesundheitsfürsorge verwendet, um verschiedene Aspekte der Patientenversorgung zu dokumentieren. Sie können dazu beitragen, die Behandlungsqualität und den Therapieverlauf zu verbessern, indem sie wichtige Informationen für zukünftige Behandler bereitstellen.

Wichtig bei solchen Berichten ist es, die Privatsphäre des Patienten zu respektieren und die erforderlichen Datenschutzmaßnahmen zu treffen. Zudem sollte der Bericht präzise und wissenschaftlich fundiert sein und nur von autorisierten Personen eingesehen werden.

Es ist wichtig, dass in solchen Berichten auch Empfehlungen enthalten sind, um eine stetige und angemessene Versorgung des Patienten sicherzustellen. Hierzu können beispielsweise Kontaktdaten von zukünftigen Behaltern oder Anweisungen zur weiteren Behandlung angegeben werden.

In diesem speziellen Fall könnten die Empfehlungen auch den Ausdruck des Wunsches des Patienten reflektieren, bestimmte Medikamente zu reduzieren oder zu wechseln, sowie die Empfehlung einer ambulanten Fortsetzung der psychotherapeutischen Behandlung. Dies könnte ein wichtiger Schritt sein, um Herr Eggli eine optimale Unterstützung für seine weitere Genesung und Lebensqualität zu bieten.

Im gesamten Bericht ist jedoch darauf zu achten, dass er die relevanten Gesetze und Verordnungen beachtet und keine vertraulichen Informationen preisgibt. Darüber hinaus sollte der Bericht regelmäßig überprüft und aktualisiert werden, um sicherzustellen, dass die Informationen aktuell sind und den aktuellen Behandlungsstand widerspiegeln.

Abschließend ist es wichtig, das Dokument von qualifizierten Fachleuten wie zertifizierte Gesundheitsfürsorger oder Ärzte erstellen zu lassen, um sicherzustellen, dass der Bericht korrekt und sinnvoll für die Patientenversorgung ist.

Zur besseren Lesbarkeit und Strukturierung werde ich den Text in kleinere Abschnitte aufteilen:

I. Diagnose:
Es wird eine schwere rezidivierende depressive Episode diagnostiziert, basierend auf dem depressiven Affekt, der Antriebsminderung und Freudlosigkeit sowie Selbstabwertung, Schuldgefühlen, Schlafstörungen und pessimistischen Zukunftsperspektiven. Der MRI-Befund war unauffällig.

II. Therapieplan:
- Multimodales stationäres Behandlungskonzept: ärztlich-pharmakologische Behandlung, psychotherapeutische Einzel- & Gruppentherapie, Bezugspflege
- Pharmakotherapie: Venlafaxin (37,5 mg - 75 mg) mit tolerierbaren Nebenwirkungen wie Übelkeit, Kopfschmerz, Schwindel und Schwitzen. Verlaufs-EKG & Labore waren unauffällig.
- Psychotherapeutische Interventionen: Identifizierung und Herausforderung negativer Gedanken über berufliche Leistungsfähigkeit, kognitive Umstrukturierung, Selbstwertgefühlstärkung, Entspannung & Stressbewältigungstechniken.

III. Sozialer und somatischer Status:
- Rückkehr in die bestehenden Wohn- & Arbeitsverhältnisse
- Keine organischen Hinweise im MRI

IV. Verlauf:
Im stationären Setting verbesserte sich das Gedankenkreisen, Antriebsminderung, Freudempfinden sowie die Zukunftsperspektive. Bei Austritt lag ein weitgehend remittiertes depressives Syndrom ohne akute Suizidalität vor.

V. Nachsorgemaßnahmen:
- Ambulante psychiatrische Weiterbetreuung: Termin bei Dr. Zwanghaft am 31.6.2024
- Hausärztliche Betreuung durch Dr. Grundversorgung 
- Dauerhafte Alkoholabstinenz empfohlen
- Ausschleichversuch von Venlafaxin ab ca. 12 Monaten, bei Verschlechterung erneut überdosieren
- Fortführung der psychotherapeutischen Ambulanzbehandlung mit Dr. Zwanghaft

VI. Reservemedikation und Empfehlungen:
- LISINOPRIL: 5 mg Filmtabl (Lisinopril)
- DAFALGAN: 500 mg Tabl (Paracetamol) nur in Reserve
- Keine anderen Medikamente im Austrittsbericht, da keine Anwendung geplant

VII. Abschlusswort:
Stabiler psychischer Zustand und keine Hinweise auf akute Selbst- oder Fremdgefährdung beim Entlassen in bestehende Verhältnisse.

models.zephyr:7b:
Dear Patient,

This report summarizes the diagnosis, treatment plan, and clinical findings during your recent hospitalization at our psychiatric ward for a major depressive episode with antipsychotic medication (Lithium) usage.

Diagnosis:
After a thorough assessment of your symptoms, medical history, and laboratory tests, we diagnosed you with a severe recurrent major depressive episode. This diagnosis was further supported by a personal history of depression, as well as the presence of mood-related symptoms such as depressed mood, anhedonia (loss of interest or pleasure), changes in appetite and sleep patterns, feelings of guilt and low self-worth, and pessimistic thoughts about the future.

Treatment Plan:
As part of your treatment plan, we initially prescribed Lithium at a starting dose of 37.5 mg per day to manage your symptoms. We then gradually increased the dosage up to 900 mg per day over several weeks to achieve the target therapeutic level. Antidepressant medication (Venlafaxin) was also initiated at a low dose of 37.5 mg per day and gradually titrated to reach the optimal therapeutic range. Additionally, we provided you with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and stress-management techniques as part of your multidisciplinary treatment plan.

Clinical Findings:
During your hospitalization, you demonstrated significant improvement in mood and functioning. Your depressive symptoms lessened, and you reported increased levels of energy, motivation, and optimism about the future. We also observed improvements in your cognition, as well as a decrease in suicidal ideation.

Lab results during admission were unremarkable except for an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) on day 7, which is likely due to infection-related inflammation and resolved spontaneously by discharge. ECGs performed during hospitalization showed no significant findings, and we did not observe any abnormalities in your liver or kidney function.

During the last week of hospitalization, Lithium levels were stable at a therapeutic range, and Venlafaxin levels were also within the optimal range. We recommended that you continue taking these medications upon discharge to maintain their effects.

Recommendations:
Upon discharge, we recommend that you continue your psychotherapy sessions with Dr. Zwanghaft for ongoing support in managing your depression and maintaining the gains made during hospitalization. We also suggest that you schedule a follow-up appointment with your primary care physician to monitor your blood pressure, liver function tests, and kidney function tests regularly as Lithium usage can cause these side effects.

We encourage you to continue making healthy lifestyle choices, such as regular exercise, a balanced diet, and getting enough sleep. Additionally, we recommend that you avoid excessive alcohol consumption and limit caffeine intake to improve your overall well-being. If you experience any side effects or concerns regarding your medications, please do not hesitate to contact us for further guidance.

We wish you all the best in your continued recovery, and we are available to answer any questions you may have or provide additional support as needed.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]
Psychiatrist at XYZ Hospital.

models.mistral:7b-instruct:
Dear [Recipient],

   I am sending you this letter regarding the case of our patient, Mr. Eggli. After a comprehensive evaluation and treatment process, we have come to the following conclusions:

   Diagnosis: We diagnosed Mr. Eggli with a severe recurrent depressive episode based on his depressive affect, decreased motivation, low self-esteem, guilt feelings, sleep disturbances, and pessimistic future perspective, as well as indications of previous depressive episodes in his biographical history.

   Differential diagnosis: We also considered the possibility of an uncertain avoidant personality structure, but we did not diagnose a personality disorder due to the current strong affective symptomatology. No specific organic etiology was suggested, particularly given the unremarkable MRI scan.

   Treatment plan: During his hospital stay, Mr. Eggli participated in our multimodal treatment program, which included medical pharmacological therapy, individual and group psychotherapy, as well as social support.

   Pharmacological approach: We decided to start Venlafaxine with a low initial dose of 37.5 mg per day, gradually increasing it up to the target dose of 75 mg per day. During the dosage adjustment process, typical but tolerable side effects occurred, such as nausea, headache, dizziness, and increased sweating. These side effects resolved completely over time. Routine ECGs and lab tests were unremarkable throughout the treatment period.

   Psychotherapeutic themes: We found that Mr. Eggli frequently had negative thoughts about his professional performance, which led to feelings of worthlessness. In therapy, he learned to identify these thoughts and question them. A coping strategy was developed by recording past achievements or reflecting on positive feedback from colleagues and superiors. Cognitive restructuring techniques were also used in individual and group sessions to help him change his thinking patterns and improve his self-worth. Relaxation and stress management techniques were also taught to help him better cope with occupational challenges and enhance his wellbeing.

   Social situation: Upon discharge, Mr. Eggli returned to his rented apartment and existing employment relationships.

   Outcome: There was an improvement in thought content, motivation, mood, and future perspective during the course of treatment. At discharge, there was a largely remitted depressive syndrome without indications of acute suicidal ideation. We are releasing Mr. Eggli in stable psychological condition, with no signs of acute self- or other-harm risk in his presumed ongoing housing and employment situations.

   Medication at discharge:
   - Lisinopril 5 mg film-coated tablet (Lisinopril)
   - Venlafaxine 75 mg film-coated tablet (Venlafaxine)
   - Dafalgan 500 mg tablet (Paracetamol)
   Procedure: 1-0-0-0 (tablets) Daily, in reserve; 1.00 tablet Maximum/24 hours: maximum 3.00 tablets

   For further ambulatory psychiatric follow-up, we have scheduled an appointment for Mr. Eggli with Dr. Zwanghaft on June 31, 2024. His primary care will continue to be provided by Dr. Grundversorgung.

   We recommend lifelong abstinence from alcohol after stabilization in the outpatient setting. Upon stabilization, we suggest a tapering-off attempt of Venlafaxine at the earliest in about 12-24 months; if there is a relapse, a further dose adjustment may be considered. We recommend continuation of outpatient psychotherapy, which Mr. Eggli wishes to discuss with Dr. Zwanghaft.

   Please feel free to contact us if you have any questions or need assistance. This document has been electronically viewed and is valid without a signature.

   Best regards,
   [Your Name]
